newsitem.title: USA: D.C. airport reopened after suspected gas leak.
newsitem.headline: D.C. airport reopened after suspected gas leak.

text.p: Washington's National Airport was partially evacuated and flights were diverted to a nearby airport on Sunday after gas fumes were detected in the lobby of the main terminal, airport officials said.
Spokesman Jonathan Gaffney said the lobby of the main terminal and the control tower were reopened at 8 p.m. EST after two hours.
"We're not back to normal, but we're getting there," he said.
Spokeswoman Tara Hamilton said the local gas company, Washington Gas, had arrived on the scene, turned off the gas and an investigation into the cause of the odor was underway.
It was still unclear what caused the fumes in the lobby, which houses the ticket counters of United Airlines, Air Canada and Trans World Airways (TWA).
She later told reporters that hazardous material investigators had removed a trash can that was emitting a suspicious odor, although it was unclear what was inside.
A total of six flights had been diverted to Washington Dulles International Airport, Gaffney said.
Passengers and airport employees were evacuated only from the lobby area, the spokeswoman said.

Hamilton said the incident appeared unrelated to a similar one several months ago in which a transit bus hit a gas pipeline in a tunnel on the airport grounds, forcing the evacuation of another smaller terminal and delaying flights for hours.
The fumes were first detected between 5:30 p.m. and 6 p.m., she said.
